Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2012
Award.AbstractNarration:
Mutual mate choice in the bushcricket Ephippiger diurnus

Few decisions are more important for individual fitness than choosing when and with whom to mate. Although mate choice is a widely studied topic, little is known about cases where mutual mate choice occurs. The bushcricket Ephippiger diurnus provides a unique opportunity to explore mutual mate choice: females choose males based on their acoustic calls, and males provide females with a nuptial gift (nutritious spermatophores). The fellow will test the hypothesis that males display mate choice, and that their degree of choosiness depends on their nutritional status. The fellow will also investigate the relationship between the traits females use to evaluate males and male quality. Finally, the interplay between male and female choice as it relates to body mass will be investigated. Interactions between male and female preferences have received little attention, yet are likely to be an important selective force on mate choice in many species.

In this project the Fellow will receive training in working with Orthopterans, in recording and analyzing acoustic signals, and in analyzing spermatophore quality. The Fellow will pursue several outreach activities through the host institution. She will engage students in her research, and she is especially interested in engaging students from groups that are underrepresented in science. This project will foster integration between research and teaching: the Fellow will teach Behavioral Biology at the University of Tours using inquiry-based activities that will involve having students work on independent research projects relating to her research. This international teaching experience will expose the fellow to a rich cultural diversity and broaden her perspectives in the classroom, improving her skills at engaging students from diverse backgrounds.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit

In many animal species, males produce conspicuous and exaggerated traits to attract females and compete with other males, even though these traits come at a high energetic cost. Males of most katydid species produce mating songs and nuptial gifts, which are large packets of sperm and nutrients that they transfer to females while mating. The European katydid Ephippiger diurnus is distributed as several geographically-isolated populations where there is striking inter-population variation in male song, notably in the song length. The songs are composed of pulses; some populations produce short calls that consist of only one or two pulses, while others produce long calls of up to 8 pulses. All of them produce remarkably large nuptial gifts that correspond to up to 40% of a male’s body weight. The main goal of this project was to investigate causes and consequences of song variation among populations. We found that populations that make long calls spend more energy calling, and in those populations there are tradeoffs between calling and nuptial gifts, as well as between calling and immune function. Those tradeoffs are not seen in populations with short calls, since calling is less costly for them and they are therefore less limited in their energy budget. We also found inter-population variation in female preferences: in long-call populations, females prefer longer calls, with even more syllable than males are producing. In short call populations, females prefer short calls with one to two syllables, and discriminate against long calls. These inter-population differences in songs, tradeoffs and preferences seem to reflect the evolutionary history of the species, and may also contribute to further divergence between populations, leading to speciation.

 

Broader impacts

The main broader impact goal of this postdoctoral fellowship was in the professional development of the PI. The PI received training in research skills, mentoring and teaching. She worked with several undergraduate researchers and mentored a masters student. She established collaborations and attended scientific meetings, and received training in several data collecting and analysis skills. She also received mentoring in teaching. She taught two college courses for which she developed inquiry-based methodologies. These skills were fundamental to prepare her for an Assistant Professor position.

This project also provided the opportunity for undergraduates and graduate students to get involved. These individuals also received training in multiple data collection and analysis skills, such as collecting and rearing insects, recording and analyzing acoustic and ultra-sonic signals, and using a motion compensation sphere to test female preferences.
